title: Florida Gov. DeSantis Seeks to End Walt Disney World's Special Tax District; Disney has faced backlash in state amid 'Don't Say Gay' controversy
text:
Disney remained silent on the bill until it passed, when the company then vowed to fight for its repeal and to fight other bills like it in other states.

Disney didn't immediately respond to a request for comment Tuesday morning.

Mr. DeSantis said during a press conference that the proclamation he signed Tuesday targets ending the Reedy Creek Improvement District, which was created in 1967 to allow landowners and companies, including Disney, to oversee land use and environmental protections as well as provide services, such as electrical power and emergency fire or medical services.

The district includes Walt Disney World's four theme parks, two water parks, a sports complex and its hotels, stores and restaurants.

Florida's legislature is expected to meet this week.
